choices.D: Router B is not advertising 10.1.1.0/24 to Router C due to split horizon.
choices.C: Router D is not advertising 10.1.1.0/24 to Router C due to split horizon.
choices.B: Router B is not advertising 10.1.1.0/24 to Router C because Router C is its feasible successor.
choices.A: Router D is not advertising 10.1.1.0/24 to Router C because Router C is its feasible successor.

discussion.content: Per the diagram, there is no multipoint interface, so split-horizon is not in effect. Obviously, the left path has a higher metric.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. In this network, all routers are configured to run EIGRP on all interfaces. All interface bandwidths are set to 1000, and the delays are configured as shown. In the topology table at Router C, you see only one path towards 10.1.1.0/24. What is the reason that Router C only has one path in its topology table?
//IMG//

A switched network is being designed to support a manufacturing factory. Due to cost constraints, fiber-based connectivity is not an option. Which design allows for a stable network when there is a risk of interference from the manufacturing hardware in use on the factory floor?

discussion.content:
A could be wrong answer. There is a good post here: https://community.cisco.com/t5/switching/udld-on-twisted-pair/td-p/2109573 
I would better use B. Interference can, in theory cause something, but not an unidirectional stuff in twisted pair.

choices.C: Design the network to include loop guard to prevent a loop in the switched network when a link has too much interference.
choices.B: Design the network to include EtherChannel bundles to prevent a single-link failure from taking down a switch interconnection point.
choices.A: Design the network to include UDLD to detect unidirectional links and take them out of service.
choices.D: Design the network to include BackboneFast on all devices to accelerate failure convergence times.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. In this network design, where should summarization occur to provide the best summarization and optimal paths during a single-failure incident as well as during normal operation?
//IMG//

choices.C: a single identical summary on 3A and 3B
choices.A: a single identical summary for all the branch offices placed on routers 1A, 1B, 2A, and 2B
choices.B: two summaries on 1A and 1B, and two summaries on 2A and 2B
choices.D: a single summary on each aggregation device for the branches connected to them

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. All routers in this network are configured to place all interfaces in OSPF area 5. R3 is the designated router on the 10.1.5.0/24 network. If you examine the OSPF database on R4, what would the network (type 2) LSA, generated by R3, contain?
//IMG//

choices.B: a connection to 10.1.5.0/24 and links to R2 and R1
choices.A: a connection to 10.1.5.0/24 and links to R3, R2, and R1
choices.D: no connections, R3 does not generate a network (type 2) LSA in this network

discussion.content: Another "turkish kebab" question. Btw, cisco interprets graceful restart and nsf equally. But, actually, they are not the same. the question is, will the redistributed BGP route stay in RIB/FIB during failure or not. i dont know and can not find 2sup equipment for tests. but would vote for C.

A would be okay if it is only the OSPF process that reloads in that case indeed forwarding is maintained and the routing table stays, Hoewever the question mentions a supervisor FORWARDING failure. --> C is correct.
A - NSF with a graceful restart aware - the neighbour will keep the route

choices.D: no WAN routes will be accessible
choices.A: via CE A and CE B

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit. The design is being proposed for use within the network. The CE devices are
OSPF graceful restart-capable, and the core devices are OSPF graceful restart-aware. The WAN advertisements received from BGP are redistributed into OSPF.
A forwarding supervisor failure event takes place on CE A. During this event, how will the routes learned from the WAN be seen on the core devices?
//IMG//
